a.g: Alif, Lam, Meem.
Allah - there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of existence.
He has sent down upon you, [O Muhammad], the Book in truth, confirming what was before it. And He revealed the Torah and the Gospel.

Before, as guidance for the people. And He revealed the Qur'an. Indeed, those who disbelieve in the verses of Allah will have a severe punishment, and Allah is exalted in Might, the Owner of Retribution.
Indeed, from Allah nothing is hidden in the earth nor in the heaven.
It is He who forms you in the wombs however He wills. There is no deity except Him, the Exalted in Might, the Wise.

It is He who has sent down to you, [O Muhammad], the Book; in it are verses [that are] precise - they are the foundation of the Book - and others unspecific. As for those in whose hearts is deviation [from truth], they will follow that of it which is unspecific, seeking discord and seeking an interpretation [suitable to them]. And no one knows its [true] interpretation except Allah. But those firm in knowledge say, "We believe in it. All [of it] is from our Lord." And no one will be reminded except those of understanding.

So we ask Allah, the Exalted, to make us among those firmly grounded in knowledge [al-rasikhuna fi al-'ilm], who say: "We believe in it; all of it is from our Lord. And none will grasp the reminder except those of understanding [ulu al-albab]."

a.g: [Who say], "Our Lord, let not our hearts deviate after You have guided us and grant us from Yourself mercy. Indeed, You are the Bestower.
Our Lord, surely You will gather the people for a Day about which there is no doubt. Indeed, Allah does not fail in His promise."
a.ihya:

Vol1 book 10
Indeed, more than one narration states: I observed the prayer [salah] of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, during a journey at night. He slept after the evening prayer [‘isha] for a time, then awoke and looked towards the horizon and said: "Our Lord, You did not create this in vain [batilan]. Glory be to You..." until he reached "...Indeed, You do not fail the promise [al-mi‘ad]." Then he took a tooth-stick [siwak] from his bedding, cleaned his teeth, performed ablution [wudu], and prayed until I thought he had prayed for as long as he had slept. Then he lay down until I thought he had slept for as long as he had prayed. Then he awoke and said what he had said the first time and did what he had done the first time. The narration was transmitted by al-Nasa’i from the narration of Humayd ibn ‘Abd al-Rahman ibn ‘Awf that a man from the Companions of the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: I said to myself while on a journey with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, "By Allah, I will observe the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him," and he mentioned something similar. And Abu al-Walid ibn Mughith narrated in the *Book of Prayer* from the narration of Ishaq ibn ‘Abd Allah ibn Abi Talhah that a man said, "I will closely observe the prayer of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him," and he mentioned the narration, and in it is that he took his tooth-stick from behind the saddle. And this indicates that it was also during a journey.

a.g: Indeed, those who disbelieve - never will their wealth or their children avail them against Allah at all. And it is they who are fuel for the Fire.
[Theirs is] like the custom of the people of Pharaoh and those before them. They denied Our signs, so Allah seized them for their sins. And Allah is severe in penalty.
Say to those who disbelieve, "You will be overcome and gathered together to Hell, and wretched is the resting place."

Already there has been for you a sign in the two armies which met - one fighting in the cause of Allah and another of disbelievers. They saw them [to be] twice their [own] number by [their] eyesight. But Allah supports with His victory whom He wills. Indeed in that is a lesson for those of vision.

Beautified for people is the love of that which they desire - of women and sons, heaped-up sums of gold and silver, fine branded horses, and cattle and tilled land. That is the enjoyment of worldly life, but Allah has with Him the best return.

Vol3 book 6a
Indeed, God the Exalted has mentioned seven of them in a single verse, saying: "Beautified for people is the love of desires [shahawat]—from women and children, and heaped-up treasures of gold and silver, and branded horses, and cattle and tilled land. That is the enjoyment of the life of the world [hayat al-dunya]." Then He reduced it in another verse to five, saying, the Mighty and Majestic: "Know that the life of the world [al-hayat al-dunya] is but play and amusement, and adornment, and mutual boasting among you, and rivalry in increase of wealth and children." Then He the Exalted reduced it in another place to two, saying the Exalted: "And the life of the world [al-hayat al-dunya] is nothing but play and amusement." Then He reduced it all to one in another place, saying: "And restrain the soul [al-nafs] from desire [al-hawa]; indeed, Paradise is the abode." For "desire" [al-hawa] is a term that gathers all the shares of the soul [al-nafs] in the world [al-dunya]; therefore, asceticism [zuhd] should be in it.

a.g: Say, "Shall I inform you of [something] better than that? For those who fear Allah will be gardens in the presence of their Lord beneath which rivers flow, wherein they abide eternally, and purified spouses and approval from Allah. And Allah is Seeing of [His] servants -
Those who say, "Our Lord, indeed we have believed, so forgive us our sins and protect us from the punishment of the Fire,"
The patient, the true, the obedient, those who spend [in the way of Allah], and those who seek forgiveness before dawn.
a.ihya:

Indeed, the Most High says: "And those who seek forgiveness [al-mustaghfirīn] in the pre-dawn hours [al-asḥār]." And He, may He be glorified and exalted, would frequently say: "Glory be to You, O Allah, and praise be to You. O Allah, forgive me. Indeed, You are the Accepter of Repentance [al-Tawwāb], the Most Merciful [al-Raḥīm]."

a.g: Allah witnesses that there is no deity except Him, and [so do] the angels and those of knowledge - [that He is] maintaining [creation] in justice. There is no deity except Him, the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 10
Indeed, those who reach this station [maqam] are divided into the strong [aqwiyya'], and their first knowledge [ma'rifa] is by Allah, the Exalted, then by Him they know other than Him. And to this first group is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: "Allah bears witness that there is no deity except Him" [3:18]. And from this is the view of some of them, when it was said to him: "By what did you know your Lord [Rabb]?" He said: "I knew my Lord [Rabb], and were it not for my Lord [Rabb], I would not have known my Lord [Rabb]."
Vol1 book 10
Indeed, God bears witness that there is no god but He, and so do the angels [al-mala'ikah] and those possessing knowledge [ulu al-'ilm], upholding justice. There is no god but He, the Almighty, the Wise. Indeed, the religion [al-din] with God is Islam. And those who were given the Book did not differ except after knowledge [al-'ilm] had come to them, out of envy among themselves. And whoever disbelieves in the verses of God, then indeed, God is swift in reckoning. Then I say: And I bear witness to what God has borne witness to for Himself, and what His angels [mala'ikah] and those possessing knowledge [ulu al-'ilm] from His creation have borne witness to. And I entrust to God this testimony [shahadah], and it is a trust [wadi'ah] for me with God, the Exalted. And I ask Him to preserve it for me until He takes me while I am upon it. O God, remove from me by it a burden [wizr], and make it for me a treasure [dhukhrah] with You, and preserve it for me, and take me while I am upon it until I meet You with it, not having changed it with any change.

a.g: Indeed, the religion in the sight of Allah is Islam. And those who were given the Scripture did not differ except after knowledge had come to them - out of jealous animosity between themselves. And whoever disbelieves in the verses of Allah, then indeed, Allah is swift in [taking] account.

So if they argue with you, say, "I have submitted myself to Allah [in Islam], and [so have] those who follow me." And say to those who were given the Scripture and [to] the unlearned, "Have you submitted yourselves?" And if they submit [in Islam], they are rightly guided; but if they turn away - then upon you is only the [duty of] notification. And Allah is Seeing of [His] servants.
Those who disbelieve in the signs of Allah and kill the prophets without right and kill those who order justice from among the people - give them tidings of a painful punishment.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book 9a
Indeed, a man stood commanding the good [al-ma'ruf], and he was killed. Then another stood and said: "They kill those who command justice [al-qist] among the people," and the arrogant one [al-mutakabbir] who opposed him and commanded him out of arrogance [kibr] was killed.

a.g: They are the ones whose deeds have become worthless in this world and the Hereafter, and for them there will be no helpers.

Do you not consider, [O Muhammad], those who were given a portion of the Scripture? They are invited to the Scripture of Allah that it should arbitrate between them; then a party of them turns away, and they are refusing.
That is because they say, "Never will the Fire touch us except for [a few] numbered days," and [because] they were deluded in their religion by what they were inventing.
So how will it be when We assemble them for a Day about which there is no doubt? And each soul will be compensated [in full for] what it earned, and they will not be wronged.

Say, "O Allah, Owner of Sovereignty, You give sovereignty to whom You will and You take sovereignty away from whom You will. You honor whom You will and You humble whom You will. In Your hand is [all] good. Indeed, You are over all things competent.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 10
Indeed, the repetition of remembrance [dhikr] and supplication [du'a] in a small measure with constancy [mudawama] is superior to much that is scattered, for the heart [qalb] is affected by constancy as the earth is affected by successive droplets which create a hollow within it. And among the most noble things upon which to be constant is the saying: "Say: O Allah, Possessor of the Kingdom [malik al-mulk], You grant the kingdom to whom You will and You take away the kingdom from whom You will; You honor whom You will and You humble whom You will. In Your hand is all good. Indeed, You are over all things competent." For in this verse is a reminder [tadhkir] that the true kingdom [mulk] and the complete disposal of affairs belong to Allah alone, so it behooves the servant ['abd] to submit to His decree [qada'] and to be humble in seeking honor ['izza] and good [khayr], for they are in His hand, Glorified is He, not by the power [hawl] of humans and their strength [quwwa].
Vol1 book 10
Indeed, say: "O Allah, Owner of Sovereignty [al-mulk], You grant sovereignty [al-mulk] to whom You will and You strip sovereignty [al-mulk] from whom You will. You honor whom You will and You humble whom You will. In Your hand is all good. Indeed, You are over all things competent. You cause the night to enter the day and You cause the day to enter the night. You bring forth the living from the dead and You bring forth the dead from the living. And You provide for whom You will without account."

a.g: You cause the night to enter the day, and You cause the day to enter the night; and You bring the living out of the dead, and You bring the dead out of the living. And You give provision to whom You will without account."

Let not believers take disbelievers as allies rather than believers. And whoever [of you] does that has nothing with Allah, except when taking precaution against them in prudence. And Allah warns you of Himself, and to Allah is the [final] destination.

a.g: Say, "Whether you conceal what is in your breasts or reveal it, Allah knows it. And He knows that which is in the heavens and that which is on the earth. And Allah is over all things competent.

The Day every soul will find what it has done of good present [before it] and what it has done of evil, it will wish that between itself and that [evil] was a great distance. And Allah warns you of Himself, and Allah is Kind to [His] servants."

Indeed, the day every soul [nafs] finds what it has done of good brought forth, and what it has done of evil—it will wish that between it and that [evil] were a great distance. And Allah warns you of Himself. So the possessors of insight [arbab al-basa'ir] from among the servants knew that Allah, Exalted is He, lies in wait for them, and that they will be questioned in the reckoning [hisab] and held accountable for the weight of an atom [mithqal al-dharr] from passing thoughts [khawatir] and glances [lahazat]. And they realized that nothing will save them from these perils except adhering to self-reckoning [muhasaba] and sincere self-observation [muraqaba], and holding the soul [nafs] to account for every breath [anfas] and movement [harakat], and reckoning with it for every passing thought [khawatir] and glance [lahazat]. For whoever holds his soul [nafs] to account before he is held to account, his reckoning [hisab] on the Day of Standing [al-qiyamah] will be light, his answer will be present when questioned, and his return [ma'ab] and outcome [manqalab] will be good. And whoever does not hold his soul [nafs] to account, his regrets [hasrat] will be prolonged, and his halts [waqfat] in the plains ['arasat] of the Day of Standing [al-qiyamah] will be lengthy, and his evil deeds [sayyi'at] will lead him to disgrace [khizy] and contempt [maqt]. So when this was unveiled to them, they knew that nothing would save them from it except obedience to Allah. And He has commanded them to patience [sabr] and steadfast vigilance [murabata], so He, Mighty and Majestic, said: "O you who have believed, be patient and endure and remain steadfast and fear Allah that you may be successful." So they made their souls [anfus] steadfast first by mutual pledging [musharata], then by self-observation [muraqaba], then by self-reckoning [muhasaba], then by self-punishment [mu'aqaba], then by striving [mujahada], then by self-reproof [mu'ataba]. Thus, for them in steadfast vigilance [murabata] were six stations [maqamat], and it is necessary to explain them and clarify their reality [haqiqa] and virtue [fadila] and detail the works [a'mal] within them. The foundation [asl] of that is self-reckoning [muhasaba], but every reckoning [hisab] is after mutual pledging [musharata] and self-observation [muraqaba], and it is followed, in case of loss [khusran], by self-reproof [mu'ataba] and self-punishment [mu'aqaba]. So let us mention the explanation of these stations [maqamat], and with Allah is success [tawfiq].

a.g: Say, "Obey Allah and the Messenger." But if they turn away - then indeed, Allah does not like the disbelievers.

a.g: Descendants, some of them from others. And Allah is Hearing and Knowing.

[Mention, O Muhammad], when the wife of 'Imran said, "My Lord, indeed I have pledged to You what is in my womb, consecrated [for Your service], so accept this from me. Indeed, You are the Hearing, the Knowing."

But when she delivered her, she said, "My Lord, I have delivered a female." And Allah was most knowing of what she delivered, "And the male is not like the female. And I have named her Mary, and I seek refuge for her in You and [for] her descendants from Satan, the expelled [from the mercy of Allah]."

So her Lord accepted her with good acceptance and caused her to grow in a good manner and put her in the care of Zechariah. Every time Zechariah entered upon her in the prayer chamber, he found with her provision. He said, "O Mary, from where is this [coming] to you?" She said, "It is from Allah. Indeed, Allah provides for whom He wills without account."
At that, Zechariah called upon his Lord, saying, "My Lord, grant me from Yourself a good offspring. Indeed, You are the Hearer of supplication."

So the angels called him while he was standing in prayer in the chamber, "Indeed, Allah gives you good tidings of John, confirming a word from Allah and [who will be] honorable, abstaining [from women], and a prophet from among the righteous."

a.g: He said, "My Lord, how will I have a boy when I have reached old age and my wife is barren?" The angel said, "Such is Allah; He does what He wills."

He said, "My Lord, make for me a sign." He Said, "Your sign is that you will not [be able to] speak to the people for three days except by gesture. And remember your Lord much and exalt [Him with praise] in the evening and the morning."
And [mention] when the angels said, "O Mary, indeed Allah has chosen you and purified you and chosen you above the women of the worlds.
O Mary, be devoutly obedient to your Lord and prostrate and bow with those who bow [in prayer]."

That is from the news of the unseen which We reveal to you, [O Muhammad]. And you were not with them when they cast their pens as to which of them should be responsible for Mary. Nor were you with them when they disputed.

[And mention] when the angels said, "O Mary, indeed Allah gives you good tidings of a word from Him, whose name will be the Messiah, Jesus, the son of Mary - distinguished in this world and the Hereafter and among those brought near [to Allah].
He will speak to the people in the cradle and in maturity and will be of the righteous."
She said, "My Lord, how will I have a child when no man has touched me?" [The angel] said, "Such is Allah; He creates what He wills. When He decrees a matter, He only says to it, 'Be,' and it is.
And He will teach him writing and wisdom and the Torah and the Gospel

And [make him] a messenger to the Children of Israel, [who will say], 'Indeed I have come to you with a sign from your Lord in that I design for you from clay [that which is] like the form of a bird, then I breathe into it and it becomes a bird by permission of Allah. And I cure the blind and the leper, and I give life to the dead - by permission of Allah. And I inform you of what you eat and what you store in your houses. Indeed in that is a sign for you, if you are believers.

And [I have come] confirming what was before me of the Torah and to make lawful for you some of what was forbidden to you. And I have come to you with a sign from your Lord, so fear Allah and obey me.
Indeed, Allah is my Lord and your Lord, so worship Him. That is the straight path."

But when Jesus felt [persistence in] disbelief from them, he said, "Who are my supporters for [the cause of] Allah?" The disciples said, "We are supporters for Allah. We have believed in Allah and testify that we are Muslims [submitting to Him].
Our Lord, we have believed in what You revealed and have followed the messenger Jesus, so register us among the witnesses [to truth]."

And it has been narrated that he, peace be upon him, recited a portion of Surah Yunus, and when he reached the mention of Musa and Fir'aun, he cut it short and performed ruku'. Vol3 book 10a
Indeed, whoever believes in Him is delivered from this delusion [ghurur]. For the origin of this delusion [ghurur] is ignorance [jahl] of Allah and His attributes. For whoever knows Him [man 'arafahu] does not feel secure from His devising [makkir], nor is he deluded by such false imaginings. And look to Pharaoh and Haman and Korah, and to the kings of the earth, and what befell them—how Allah was gracious to them at first, then utterly destroyed them! So the Almighty said, "Do you perceive from them anyone?" (Quran 44:28). And Allah the Almighty has warned of His devising [makkir] and His gradual enticement [istidraj], saying, "So none feels secure from the devising [makkir] of Allah except the people who are the losers" (Quran 7:99). And the Almighty said, "And they devised a devising [makkir], and We devised a devising [makkir], while they were not aware" (Quran 27:50). And the Almighty said, "And they devised [makarū], and Allah devised [makar], and Allah is the best of devisers [khayru al-mākirīn]" (Quran 3:54). And the Almighty said, "Indeed, they are planning a plan [kayd], and I am planning a plan [kayd]. So give respite to the disbelievers; respite them a little" (Quran 86:15-17). So just as it is not permissible for a neglected servant to infer from his master's neglect of him and enabling him with blessings that the master loves him—rather, he should fear that this may be a devising [makkir] and a plot [kayd] from him, even though the master did not warn him of his own devising—then how much more incumbent is this regarding Allah the Almighty, with His warning of His gradual enticement [istidraj]! Therefore, whoever feels secure from the devising [makkir] of Allah is deluded [maghṭurr]. And the origin of this delusion [ghurur] is that he inferred from the blessings of the world [ni'am al-dunyā] that he is honored [karīm] with that Bestower, while it is possible that this is evidence of degradation [hawan]. But that possibility does not accord with desire [hawā]. So Satan, through the medium of desire [hawā], inclines the heart [qalb] towards what agrees with it, which is believing its indication of honor [karāmah]. And this is the definition of delusion [ghurur].

a.g: [Mention] when Allah said, "O Jesus, indeed I will take you and raise you to Myself and purify you from those who disbelieve and make those who follow you [in submission to Allah alone] superior to those who disbelieve until the Day of Resurrection. Then to Me is your return, and I will judge between you concerning that in which you used to differ.
And as for those who disbelieved, I will punish them with a severe punishment in this world and the Hereafter, and they will have no helpers."
But as for those who believed and did righteous deeds, He will give them in full their rewards, and Allah does not like the wrongdoers.
This is what We recite to you, [O Muhammad], of [Our] verses and the precise [and wise] message.
Indeed, the example of Jesus to Allah is like that of Adam. He created Him from dust; then He said to him, "Be," and he was.
The truth is from your Lord, so do not be among the doubters.

Then whoever argues with you about it after [this] knowledge has come to you - say, "Come, let us call our sons and your sons, our women and your women, ourselves and yourselves, then supplicate earnestly [together] and invoke the curse of Allah upon the liars [among us]."

j2 k10
Indeed, with a sound chain [isnad], he—peace and blessings be upon him—called the Christians [al-Nasara] to the mutual imprecation [al-mubahala], but they refrained. So he—peace and blessings be upon him—made known to them that if they did that, they would perish. Thus, they knew the truth [sihha] of his statement, so they refrained. A narration: He called the Christians to the mutual imprecation and informed them that if they did that, they would perish, so they refrained. Al-Bukhari transmitted it from the narration of Ibn 'Abbas, within the course of a narration: "And if those who would engage in mutual imprecation with the Messenger of Allah—peace and blessings be upon him—had gone forth, they would have returned finding neither wealth [mala] nor family [ahla]."

a.g: Indeed, this is the true narration. And there is no deity except Allah. And indeed, Allah is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
But if they turn away, then indeed - Allah is Knowing of the corrupters.

Say, "O People of the Scripture, come to a word that is equitable between us and you - that we will not worship except Allah and not associate anything with Him and not take one another as lords instead of Allah." But if they turn away, then say, "Bear witness that we are Muslims [submitting to Him]."
O People of the Scripture, why do you argue about Abraham while the Torah and the Gospel were not revealed until after him? Then will you not reason?
Here you are - those who have argued about that of which you have [some] knowledge, but why do you argue about that of which you have no knowledge? And Allah knows, while you know not.
Abraham was neither a Jew nor a Christian, but he was one inclining toward truth, a Muslim [submitting to Allah]. And he was not of the polytheists.

Indeed, the most worthy of Abraham among the people are those who followed him [in submission to Allah] and this prophet, and those who believe [in his message]. And Allah is the ally of the believers.
A faction of the people of the Scripture wish they could mislead you. But they do not mislead except themselves, and they perceive [it] not.
O People of the Scripture, why do you disbelieve in the verses of Allah while you witness [to their truth]?
O People of the Scripture, why do you confuse the truth with falsehood and conceal the truth while you know [it]?

And a faction of the People of the Scripture say [to each other], "Believe in that which was revealed to the believers at the beginning of the day and reject it at its end that perhaps they will abandon their religion,

And do not trust except those who follow your religion." Say, "Indeed, the [true] guidance is the guidance of Allah. [Do you fear] lest someone be given [knowledge] like you were given or that they would [thereby] argue with you before your Lord?" Say, "Indeed, [all] bounty is in the hand of Allah - He grants it to whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing and Wise."
He selects for His mercy whom He wills. And Allah is the possessor of great bounty.

And among the People of the Scripture is he who, if you entrust him with a great amount [of wealth], he will return it to you. And among them is he who, if you entrust him with a [single] silver coin, he will not return it to you unless you are constantly standing over him [demanding it]. That is because they say, "There is no blame upon us concerning the unlearned." And they speak untruth about Allah while they know [it].
But yes, whoever fulfills his commitment and fears Allah - then indeed, Allah loves those who fear Him.

Indeed, those who exchange the covenant of Allah and their [own] oaths for a small price will have no share in the Hereafter, and Allah will not speak to them or look at them on the Day of Resurrection, nor will He purify them; and they will have a painful punishment.

And indeed, there is among them a party who alter the Scripture with their tongues so you may think it is from the Scripture, but it is not from the Scripture. And they say, "This is from Allah," but it is not from Allah. And they speak untruth about Allah while they know.

It is not for a human [prophet] that Allah should give him the Scripture and authority and prophethood and then he would say to the people, "Be servants to me rather than Allah," but [instead, he would say], "Be pious scholars of the Lord because of what you have taught of the Scripture and because of what you have studied."

Vol3 book5a
Indeed, it is said concerning His Exalted's statement, "Rabbāniyyīn [ربانيين]" – that is, the forbearing [ḥulamāʾ حلماء], the learned [ʿulamāʾ علماء]. And from Al-Ḥasan concerning His Exalted's statement, "And when the ignorant [al-jāhilūn الجاهلون] address them, they say, 'Peace [salāman سلاماً]'" – he said: They are forbearing [ḥulamāʾ حلماء]; if ignorance is shown to them, they do not respond with ignorance. And ʿAṭāʾ ibn Abī Rabāḥ said concerning, "And they walk upon the earth with humility [hawnan هوناً]" – that is, they are forbearing [ḥulamāʾ حلماء]. And Ibn Abī Ḥabīb said concerning His Mighty and Majestic's statement, "And in maturity [wa-kahlan وكهلا]" – he said it: The mature one [al-kahl الكهل] is the ultimate point of forbearance [ḥilm حلم]. And Mujāhid said concerning, "And when they pass by idle talk, they pass by with dignity [karāman كراما]" – that is, when they are wronged, they overlook it.

a.g: Nor could he order you to take the angels and prophets as lords. Would he order you to disbelief after you had been Muslims?

And [recall, O People of the Scripture], when Allah took the covenant of the prophets, [saying], "Whatever I give you of the Scripture and wisdom and then there comes to you a messenger confirming what is with you, you [must] believe in him and support him." [Allah] said, "Have you acknowledged and taken upon that My commitment?" They said, "We have acknowledged it." He said, "Then bear witness, and I am with you among the witnesses."
And whoever turned away after that - they were the defiantly disobedient.
So is it other than the religion of Allah they desire, while to Him have submitted [all] those within the heavens and earth, willingly or by compulsion, and to Him they will be returned?

Say, "We have believed in Allah and in what was revealed to us and what was revealed to Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, and the Descendants, and in what was given to Moses and Jesus and to the prophets from their Lord. We make no distinction between any of them, and we are Muslims [submitting] to Him."
And whoever desires other than Islam as religion - never will it be accepted from him, and he, in the Hereafter, will be among the losers.
How shall Allah guide a people who disbelieved after their belief and had witnessed that the Messenger is true and clear signs had come to them? And Allah does not guide the wrongdoing people.
Those - their recompense will be that upon them is the curse of Allah and the angels and the people, all together,
Abiding eternally therein. The punishment will not be lightened for them, nor will they be reprieved.
Except for those who repent after that and correct themselves. For indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
Indeed, those who reject the message after their belief and then increase in disbelief - never will their [claimed] repentance be accepted, and they are the ones astray.

Indeed, those who disbelieve and die while they are disbelievers - never would the [whole] capacity of the earth in gold be accepted from one of them if he would [seek to] ransom himself with it. For those there will be a painful punishment, and they will have no helpers.
Never will you attain the good [reward] until you spend [in the way of Allah] from that which you love. And whatever you spend - indeed, Allah is Knowing of it.

And whoever invents about Allah untruth after that - then those are [truly] the wrongdoers.
Say, "Allah has told the truth. So follow the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth; and he was not of the polytheists."
Indeed, the first House [of worship] established for mankind was that at Makkah - blessed and a guidance for the worlds.

In it are clear signs [such as] the standing place of Abraham. And whoever enters it shall be safe. And [due] to Allah from the people is a pilgrimage to the House - for whoever is able to find thereto a way. But whoever disbelieves - then indeed, Allah is free from need of the worlds.

Indeed, Allah the Exalted has said: "And pilgrimage to the House is a duty owed to Allah by all who can afford a way to it." And if it becomes obligatory upon a person to give in charity [tasadduq] whatever exceeds his need, in a situation where he strongly suspects its prohibition, then the alms-tax [zakat] is more deserving of being obligatory.

a.g: Say, "O People of the Scripture, why do you disbelieve in the verses of Allah while Allah is Witness over what you do?"

Say, "O People of the Scripture, why do you avert from the way of Allah those who believe, seeking to make it [seem] deviant, while you are witnesses [to the truth]? And Allah is not unaware of what you do."
O you who have believed, if you obey a party of those who were given the Scripture, they would turn you back, after your belief, [to being] unbelievers.
And how could you disbelieve while to you are being recited the verses of Allah and among you is His Messenger? And whoever holds firmly to Allah has [indeed] been guided to a straight path.
O you who have believed, fear Allah as He should be feared and do not die except as Muslims [in submission to Him].

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k08
Indeed, the word of the Almighty: "Fear Allah [taqwa] as He should be feared." As for the first, it is the fear of the general creation, and it is attained by the fundamental faith in Paradise and Hell, and that they are two recompenses for obedience and disobedience. Its weakness is due to heedlessness [ghafla] and the weakness of faith. Heedlessness is only removed by reminder and admonition, and by persistent reflection on the terrors of the Day of Resurrection and the varieties of punishment in the Hereafter. It is also removed by looking upon those who fear, keeping their company, and witnessing their states. If witnessing is missed, then hearing is not devoid of effect. As for the second, which is the higher, it is that Allah is the One feared—meaning that the servant fears the veil [hijab] from Him and hopes for proximity to Him. Dhu al-Nun, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "The fear of Hell, in the presence of the fear of separation, is like a drop dripped into a vast ocean." This is the awe [khashya] of the learned, as Allah the Exalted said: "Only those of His servants who have knowledge fear Allah." The general believers also have a share of this awe, but it is merely by imitation [taqlid]—it is like a child's fear of a snake, imitating his father. That is not based on insight [basira], so it is no wonder it weakens and vanishes quickly. Indeed, the child may see the snake-charmer proceed to take the snake, look at him, be deceived by him, and dare to take it, imitating him, just as he refrained from taking it by imitating his father. Imitative beliefs are generally weak, unless they are strengthened by constantly witnessing their confirming causes and by persisting in their requirements—in multiplying acts of obedience and avoiding sins for a long duration, continuously. Therefore, whoever ascends to the pinnacle of knowledge [ma'rifa] and knows Allah the Exalted, fears Him by necessity. He does not need a remedy to bring about fear, just as one who knows the lion and sees himself fallen into its claws does not need a remedy to bring fear to his heart. Rather, he fears it by necessity, whether he wills or not. For this reason, Allah the Exalted inspired to David, peace be upon him: "Fear Me as you fear the predatory lion." There is no means to bring about fear of the predatory lion except knowing the lion and knowing one has fallen into its claws. So he needs no means. Thus, whoever knows Allah the Exalted knows that He does what He wills and does not care, and He decrees what He desires and does not fear. He brought the angels near without a prior means, and He banished Iblis without a past crime. Rather, His attribute is what His statement translates: "These are in Paradise, and I do not care."

a.g: And hold firmly to the rope of Allah all together and do not become divided. And remember the favor of Allah upon you - when you were enemies and He brought your hearts together and you became, by His favor, brothers. And you were on the edge of a pit of the Fire, and He saved you from it. Thus does Allah make clear to you His verses that you may be guided.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k05
And the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "When the people of the Fire [ahl al-nar] gather in the Fire, and with them, whomever God wills from the people of the Qiblah [ahl al-qiblah], the disbelievers [kuffar] will say to the Muslims: 'Were you not Muslims?' They will say: 'Yes.' So they will say: 'What did your Islam [islam] avail you, since you are with us in the Fire?' They will say: 'We had sins [dhunub], so we were taken by them.' Then God, Mighty and Majestic, hears what they said, and He commands that whoever was in the Fire from the people of the Qiblah be brought out, so they are brought out. When the disbelievers see that, they say: 'If only we had been Muslims, so we could be brought out as they were brought out.'" Then the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, recited: "Often those who disbelieve wish that they had been Muslims [muslimun]." And it is narrated that a Bedouin heard Ibn Abbas reciting: "And you were on the brink of a pit of the Fire [nar], so He saved you from it." So the Bedouin said: "By God, He did not save you from it while He intends to cast you into it!" So Ibn Abbas said: "Take it from one who is not a jurist [faqih]."

[wa-ltakun minkum ummatun] is a command [amr], and the outward meaning of the command is obligation. And in it is the clarification that success [al-falah] is contingent upon it, for He specified and said, "...and it is they who are the successful." [wa-ula'ika hum al-muflihun]. And in it is the clarification that it is a collective obligation [fard kifayah], not an individual obligation [fard 'ayn], and that if a community [ummah] establishes it, the obligation falls away from the others, for He did not say, "Be, all of you, enjoining good," but rather He said, "And let there be from you a community..." Therefore, whenever one or a group establishes it, the burden [al-haraj] falls away from the others. And success [al-falah] is specifically for those who establish it and carry it out directly. And if all of creation were to neglect it, the burden [al-haraj] would inevitably encompass all those capable of it, without doubt.

Know that there is no envy [hasad] except concerning a blessing [ni'mah]. So when God bestows a blessing upon your brother, you have two states concerning it: The first is that you dislike that blessing and love its removal. This state is called envy [hasad]. Thus, the definition of envy is disliking the blessing and loving its removal from the one upon whom it was bestowed. As for the first, it is forbidden in every circumstance, except for a blessing that a wicked person or an unbeliever has attained, and he uses it to stir up strife [fitnah], corrupt relationships, and harm the truth. Then your dislike of it and your love for its removal does not harm you, for you do not love its removal inasmuch as it is a blessing, but rather inasmuch as it is an instrument of corruption. If you were secure from his corruption, his blessing would not grieve you. To this, the Qur'an alluded in His saying: "If good befalls you, it grieves them, and if evil strikes you, they rejoice at it." This rejoicing is gloating [shamatah], and envy and gloating are concomitant.

Indeed, know that the reality of good character [husn al-khuluq] and bad character [su' al-khuluq]—people have spoken about the reality of good character and what it is, yet they did not address its true essence; rather, they addressed its fruits. Then they did not encompass all of its fruits, but each one mentioned from its fruits what occurred to him and what was present in his mind, and they did not devote care to mentioning its definition and its reality with all of its fruits in detail and comprehensiveness. And lifting the veil from the reality is more important than transmitting differing statements. So We say: *Khulq* and *khalq* are two expressions used together. It is said: 'So-and-so is of good *khulq* and *khalq*'—meaning good in the inward [batin] and the outward [zahir]. For *khalq* is intended as the outward form, and *khulq* is intended as the inward form. That is because the human is composed of a body perceived by sight [basar] and of a spirit [ruh] and soul [nafs] perceived by insight [basira]. And each one of them has a state [haya] and a form [sura], either ugly or beautiful. And the soul [nafs] perceived by insight is of greater stature than the body perceived by sight. And for that, Allah magnified its affair by attributing it to Himself when He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, I am creating a human from clay. So when I have proportioned him and breathed into him of My spirit [ruh], then fall down to him in prostration." Thus He pointed out that the body is ascribed to the clay and the spirit [ruh] to the Lord of the worlds. And what is intended by spirit [ruh] and soul [nafs] in this context is one. Thus, character [khuluq] is an expression for a firmly established state [haya] in the soul [nafs], from which actions issue forth with ease and facility, without need for thought and deliberation. If the state is such that beautiful, praiseworthy actions—by reason [aql] and by law [shar']—issue forth from it, that state is called good character [khuluq hasan]. And if what issues forth from it are ugly actions, the state which is the source is called bad character [khuluq sayyi']. And We only said it is a firmly established state because one from whom spending wealth occurs rarely due to a transient need is not said to have the character [khuluq] of generosity, unless that becomes firmly established in his soul [nafs] with firm rootedness. And We stipulated that actions issue forth from it with ease. And He, the Exalted, said: "And those who restrain anger [ghayz] and pardon the people," and He did not say 'those devoid of anger.' Thus, He returned anger [ghadab] and desire [shahwa] to a state of moderation [i'tidal] such that neither of them overpowers the intellect [aql] nor overcomes it. Rather, the intellect [aql] is the controller of them and the dominant over them—this is possible. And that is what is intended by changing character [taghyir al-khuluq], for perhaps desire [shahwa] may gain mastery over a person such that his intellect [aql] is not strong enough to repel it, and he proceeds to indulge in indecencies. And through spiritual discipline [riyada] it returns to a state of moderation [i'tidal]. Thus, it indicates that this is possible, and experience [tajriba] and observation [mushahada] indicate that with an indication in which there is no doubt.

Then they did not encompass all of its fruits, but each one mentioned from its fruits what occurred to him and what was present in his mind, and they did not devote care to mentioning its definition and its reality with all of its fruits in detail and comprehensiveness. And lifting the veil from the reality is more important than transmitting differing statements. So We say: *Khulq* and *khalq* are two expressions used together. It is said: 'So-and-so is of good *khulq* and *khalq*'—meaning good in the inward [batin] and the outward [zahir]. For *khalq* is intended as the outward form, and *khulq* is intended as the inward form. That is because the human is composed of a body perceived by sight [basar] and of a spirit [ruh] and soul [nafs] perceived by insight [basira]. And each one of them has a state [haya] and a form [sura], either ugly or beautiful. And the soul [nafs] perceived by insight is of greater stature than the body perceived by sight. And for that, Allah magnified its affair by attributing it to Himself when He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, I am creating a human from clay. So when I have proportioned him and breathed into him of My spirit [ruh], then fall down to him in prostration." Thus He pointed out that the body is ascribed to the clay and the spirit [ruh] to the Lord of the worlds. And what is intended by spirit [ruh] and soul [nafs] in this context is one. Thus, character [khuluq] is an expression for a firmly established state [haya] in the soul [nafs], from which actions issue forth with ease and facility, without need for thought and deliberation. If the state is such that beautiful, praiseworthy actions—by reason [aql] and by law [shar']—issue forth from it, that state is called good character [khuluq hasan]. And if what issues forth from it are ugly actions, the state which is the source is called bad character [khuluq sayyi']. And We only said it is a firmly established state because one from whom spending wealth occurs rarely due to a transient need is not said to have the character [khuluq] of generosity, unless that becomes firmly established in his soul [nafs] with firm rootedness. And We stipulated that actions issue forth from it with ease. And He, the Exalted, said: "And those who restrain anger [ghayz] and pardon the people," and He did not say 'those devoid of anger.' Thus, He returned anger [ghadab] and desire [shahwa] to a state of moderation [i'tidal] such that neither of them overpowers the intellect [aql] nor overcomes it. Rather, the intellect [aql] is the controller of them and the dominant over them—this is possible. And that is what is intended by changing character [taghyir al-khuluq], for perhaps desire [shahwa] may gain mastery over a person such that his intellect [aql] is not strong enough to repel it, and he proceeds to indulge in indecencies. And through spiritual discipline [riyada] it returns to a state of moderation [i'tidal]. Thus, it indicates that this is possible, and experience [tajriba] and observation [mushahada] indicate that with an indication in which there is no doubt.

a.g: And those who, when they commit an immorality or wrong themselves [by transgression], remember Allah and seek forgiveness for their sins - and who can forgive sins except Allah? - and [who] do not persist in what they have done while they know.

Indeed, He, the Exalted, says: "And those who, when they commit an immorality [fahisha] or wrong themselves [zalamu anfusahum], remember Allah and seek forgiveness [istaghfaru] for their sins..." (3:135). And 'Alqamah and al-Aswad said: 'Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with them, said: "In the Book of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, there are two verses; no servant commits a sin, then recites them and seeks forgiveness [istaghfar] from Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, except that Allah, the Exalted, forgives him: 'And those who, when they commit an immorality [fahisha] or wrong themselves [zalamu anfusahum]...' the verse, and His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: 'And whoever does evil [sū'an] or wrongs himself [yazlim nafsahu], then seeks forgiveness [istaghfar] from Allah will find Allah Forgiving [ghafūran], Merciful [rahīman]' (4:110)." And He, the Mighty and Majestic, says: "So exalt [sabbih] with praise of your Lord and ask His forgiveness [istaghfirhu]. Indeed, He is ever Accepting of repentance [tawwāban]." (110:3). And He, the Exalted, says: "And those who seek forgiveness [mustaghfirīn] before dawn [asḥār]." (3:17). And He, peace and blessings be upon him, would frequently say: "Glory be to You, O Allah, and praise be to You. O Allah, forgive me. Indeed, You are the Accepter of Repentance [al-Tawwāb], the Merciful [al-Rahīm]." And He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever increases in seeking forgiveness [istighfār], Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, will make for him from every worry a relief, and from every hardship a way out, and will provide for him from where he does not expect." And He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, I seek forgiveness [astaghfir] from Allah, the Exalted, and repent [atūbu] to Him seventy times a day." This, despite the fact that He, peace and blessings be upon him, was forgiven for what preceded of his sin and what would follow. And He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, a veil [ghayyān] covers my heart [qalbī] until I seek forgiveness [astaghfir] from Allah, the Exalted, one hundred times every day." And He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever says when he retires to his bed: 'I seek forgiveness [astaghfir] from Allah, the Supreme, besides whom there is no deity, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of existence, and I repent [atūbu] to Him' three times, Allah will forgive him his sins, even if they were like the foam of the sea, or the number of the sand of 'Alij, or the number of leaves on the trees, or the number of the days of the world [dunyā]." And He, peace and blessings be upon him, said in another narration: "Whoever says that, his sins are forgiven, even if he was one who fled from the battlefield." And Hudhayfah said: "I was sharp-tongued with my family, so I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, I fear my tongue will enter me into the Fire.' So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'So where are you from seeking forgiveness [istighfār]? For indeed, I seek forgiveness [astaghfir] from Allah one hundred times a day.'" And 'A'ishah, may Allah be pleased with her, said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to me: 'If you have committed a sin, then seek forgiveness [istaghfirī] from Allah and repent [tūbī] to Him, for repentance [tawba] from the sin is remorse [nadam] and seeking forgiveness [istighfār].'" And He, peace and blessings be upon him, would say in seeking forgiveness [istighfār]: "O Allah, forgive me my misstep [khatī'atī], my ignorance [jahli], my excess [isrāfī] in my affair, and that which You know better than me. O Allah, forgive me my jest [hazli], my seriousness [jiddī], my mistake [khatā'ī], and my intentional act ['amdī]."

a.g: Those - their reward is forgiveness from their Lord and gardens beneath which rivers flow [in Paradise], wherein they will abide eternally; and excellent is the reward of the [righteous] workers.
Similar situations [as yours] have passed on before you, so proceed throughout the earth and observe how was the end of those who denied.
This [Qur'an] is a clear statement to [all] the people and a guidance and instruction for those conscious of Allah.

Indeed, God Almighty has said: "This is a clear declaration for mankind, and a guidance and an admonition for the God-conscious [muttaqin]." And Abu Yazid and others would say: "The knower [al-'alim] is not he who memorizes from a book, such that if he forgets what he has memorized, he becomes ignorant. Rather, the knower is he who takes his knowledge ['ilm] from his Lord whenever he wills, without memorization and without study. And this is the divine knowledge [al-'ilm al-rabbani]."

a.g: So do not weaken and do not grieve, and you will be superior if you are [true] believers.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j3 k01
Indeed, its abundance is that the knowledges [ma'arif] are lights [anwar], and the believers do not strive to meet Allah, the Exalted, except by their lights... Thus, by this, the disparity among people in faith [iman] becomes apparent... And Allah, the Exalted, has said: "And you are the superior ones if you are believers," a preference for the believers over the Muslims, and the intended meaning by it is the knowing believer [al-mu'min al-'arif], not the imitator [al-muqallid].

a.g: If a wound should touch you - there has already touched the [opposing] people a wound similar to it. And these days [of varying conditions] We alternate among the people so that Allah may make evident those who believe and [may] take to Himself from among you martyrs - and Allah does not like the wrongdoers -
And that Allah may purify the believers [through trials] and destroy the disbelievers.
Or do you think that you will enter Paradise while Allah has not yet made evident those of you who fight in His cause and made evident those who are steadfast?
And you had certainly wished for martyrdom before you encountered it, and you have [now] seen it [before you] while you were looking on.

Muhammad is not but a messenger. [Other] messengers have passed on before him. So if he was to die or be killed, would you turn back on your heels [to unbelief]? And he who turns back on his heels will never harm Allah at all; but Allah will reward the grateful.

Indeed, Muhammad is not but a messenger [rasul]; messengers have passed before him. So if he were to die or be killed, would you turn back on your heels? As if the people had not heard this verse except on that day.

a.g: And it is not [possible] for one to die except by permission of Allah at a decree determined. And whoever desires the reward of this world - We will give him thereof; and whoever desires the reward of the Hereafter - We will give him thereof. And we will reward the grateful.

And how many a prophet [fought and] with him fought many religious scholars. But they never lost assurance due to what afflicted them in the cause of Allah, nor did they weaken or submit. And Allah loves the steadfast.
And their words were not but that they said, "Our Lord, forgive us our sins and the excess [committed] in our affairs and plant firmly our feet and give us victory over the disbelieving people."
So Allah gave them the reward of this world and the good reward of the Hereafter. And Allah loves the doers of good.
O you who have believed, if you obey those who disbelieve, they will turn you back on your heels, and you will [then] become losers.
But Allah is your protector, and He is the best of helpers.

We will cast terror into the hearts of those who disbelieve for what they have associated with Allah of which He had not sent down [any] authority. And their refuge will be the Fire, and wretched is the residence of the wrongdoers.

And Allah had certainly fulfilled His promise to you when you were killing the enemy by His permission until [the time] when you lost courage and fell to disputing about the order [given by the Prophet] and disobeyed after He had shown you that which you love. Among you are some who desire this world, and among you are some who desire the Hereafter. Then he turned you back from them [defeated] that He might test you. And He has already forgiven you, and Allah is the possessor of bounty for the believers.

Some of them said: Indeed, Pharaoh only said, 'I am your Lord, Most High,' due to the length of well-being [ṭūl al-ʿāfiyah], for he remained for four hundred years without a headache afflicting him, nor his body suffering a fever, nor a vein throbbing in pain upon him, so he claimed lordship [rubūbiyyah] – may God curse him – and if a migraine [al-shāqīqah] had seized him for a single day, it would have preoccupied him from idle pursuits, let alone from claiming lordship [daʿwā al-rubūbiyyah].

a.g: [Remember] when you [fled and] climbed [the mountain] without looking aside at anyone while the Messenger was calling you from behind. So Allah repaid you with distress upon distress so you would not grieve for that which had escaped you [of victory and spoils of war] or [for] that which had befallen you [of injury and death]. And Allah is [fully] Acquainted with what you do.

Then after distress, He sent down upon you security [in the form of] drowsiness, overcoming a faction of you, while another faction worried about themselves, thinking of Allah other than the truth - the thought of ignorance, saying, "Is there anything for us [to have done] in this matter?" Say, "Indeed, the matter belongs completely to Allah." They conceal within themselves what they will not reveal to you. They say, "If there was anything we could have done in the matter, some of us would not have been killed right here." Say, "Even if you had been inside your houses, those decreed to be killed would have come out to their death beds." [It was] so that Allah might test what is in your breasts and purify what is in your hearts. And Allah is Knowing of that within the breasts.

Indeed, death [al-mawt] until the command of Allah comes (3:154). And from the Prophet, peace be upon him, he said: (Jibril, upon him be peace, said to me: Let Islam weep for the death of 'Umar). And from Ibn 'Abbas, he said: 'Umar was placed upon his bed, and the people surrounded him, supplicating and praying before he was raised, and I was among them. Then, none alerted me except a man who had taken hold of my shoulder. I turned, and behold, it was 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him. He invoked mercy upon 'Umar and said: "You have left behind no one whose deeds I would more love to meet Allah with than yours. By Allah, I indeed used to think that Allah would place you with your two companions. That is because I used to frequently hear the Prophet, peace be upon him, say: ('I and Abu Bakr and 'Umar went,' and 'I and Abu Bakr and 'Umar went out,' and 'I and Abu Bakr and 'Umar entered'). So I indeed used to hope—I used to think—that Allah would place you with them."

a.g: Indeed, those of you who turned back on the day the two armies met, it was Satan who caused them to slip because of some [blame] they had earned. But Allah has already forgiven them. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Forbearing.

O you who have believed, do not be like those who disbelieved and said about their brothers when they traveled through the land or went out to fight, "If they had been with us, they would not have died or have been killed," so Allah makes that [misconception] a regret within their hearts. And it is Allah who gives life and causes death, and Allah is Seeing of what you do.
And if you are killed in the cause of Allah or die - then forgiveness from Allah and mercy are better than whatever they accumulate [in this world].
And whether you die or are killed, unto Allah you will be gathered.

So by mercy from Allah, [O Muhammad], you were lenient with them. And if you had been rude [in speech] and harsh in heart, they would have disbanded from about you. So pardon them and ask forgiveness for them and consult them in the matter. And when you have decided, then rely upon Allah. Indeed, Allah loves those who rely [upon Him].
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 1
Indeed, He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, Allah loves those who rely [upon Him] [al-mutawakkilin]." And how great is a station [maqam] marked by the love [mahabbah] of Allah, the Exalted, for its possessor, and guaranteed by the sufficiency [kifayah] of Allah, the Exalted, for its circumstances. So whoever has Allah, the Exalted, as his Sufficient One [hasbuhu] and his Provider [kafihi] and his Beloved [muhibbuhu] and his Guardian [mura'ihi]: he has attained the supreme success [al-fawz al-'azim]. For the beloved [al-mahbub] is not punished, nor distanced, nor veiled.

a.g: If Allah should aid you, no one can overcome you; but if He should forsake you, who is there that can aid you after Him? And upon Allah let the believers rely.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j3 k01
Indeed, the heart [qalb] of the believer is between two fingers of the fingers of the All-Merciful [al-Rahman]—that is, between the pulling of these two hosts, and the dominant one, I mean the turning over and the transition from one party to the other. As for remaining perpetually with the party of the angels or with the party of Satan, that is rare from both sides. And these acts of obedience [ta'at] and these acts of disobedience [ma'asi] appear from the treasuries of the unseen [ghayb] to the world of witnessing [shahada] by means of the treasury of the heart [qalb], for it is from the treasuries of the dominion [malakut]. And they, when they appear, are signs by which the possessors of hearts [arbab al-qulub] know the precedent decree [sabiq al-qada']. For he who is created for Paradise, the means of obedience [ta'at] are made easy for him, and he who is created for the Fire, the means of disobedience [ma'asi] are made easy for him, and evil companions are given authority over him, and the judgment [hukm] of Satan is cast into his heart [qalb]. For he, with various judgments [ahkam], deceives the foolish by saying, "Indeed, God is Merciful, so do not care," and, "Indeed, all people do not fear God, so do not oppose them," and, "Indeed, life is long, so be patient until you repent tomorrow." He promises them and gives them false hopes, and Satan promises them nothing but delusion [ghurur]. He promises them repentance [tawba] and gives them false hopes of forgiveness [maghfira], so he destroys them by the permission of God, the Exalted, with these tricks and what is similar to them, and he expands his heart [qalb] to accept delusion [ghurur] and constricts it from accepting the truth [haqq]. And all of that is by a decree [qada'] and a measure [qadar] from God. So whom God wills to guide, He expands his breast [sadr] for submission [islam], and whom He wills to lead astray, He makes his breast [sadr] tight and constricted, as if he were climbing into the sky. "If God gives you victory, none can overcome you; but if He forsakes you, who is there that can help you after Him?" He is the Guide and the Misguider. He does what He wills and decrees what He intends. There is none to repel His decree [hukm] and none to reverse His judgment [qada']. He created Paradise and created for it its people, so He employed them with obedience [ta'a]. And He created the Fire and created for it its people, so He employed him with disobedience [ma'asi]. And He made known to creation the sign of the people of Paradise and the people of the Fire, saying, "Indeed, the righteous will be in bliss, and indeed, the wicked will be in a Blazing Fire." Then He, the Exalted, said—as narrated from His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him—"These are in Paradise, and I do not care, and these are in the Fire, and I do not care." So exalted is God, the True Sovereign; He is not questioned about what He does, but they will be questioned.

a.g: It is not [attributable] to any prophet that he would act unfaithfully [in regard to war booty]. And whoever betrays, [taking unlawfully], will come with what he took on the Day of Resurrection. Then will every soul be [fully] compensated for what it earned, and they will not be wronged.
So is one who pursues the pleasure of Allah like one who brings upon himself the anger of Allah and whose refuge is Hell? And wretched is the destination.
They are [varying] degrees in the sight of Allah, and Allah is Seeing of whatever they do.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 2
Indeed, the Most High has said: "They are degrees [darajat] with Allah." And the Most High has said: "Allah will raise those who have believed among you and those who were given knowledge by degrees [darajat]." And the Most High has said: "Not equal among you are those who spent before the conquest and fought..." the verse. And indeed, the Most High has said: "They are degrees [darajat] with Allah." And He, peace be upon him, said: "Faith [iman] is naked, and its garment is piety [taqwa]," the hadith. And He, peace be upon him, said: "Faith [iman] has between seventy and some odd branches; the lowest of them is removing harm from the road." This is what indicates the connection of the perfection of faith [iman] with deeds [a'mal].

a.g: Certainly did Allah confer [great] favor upon the believers when He sent among them a Messenger from themselves, reciting to them His verses and purifying them and teaching them the Book and wisdom, although they had been before in manifest error.

Why [is it that] when a [single] disaster struck you [on the day of Uhud], although you had struck [the enemy in the battle of Badr] with one twice as great, you said, "From where is this?" Say, "It is from yourselves." Indeed, Allah is over all things competent.
And what struck you on the day the two armies met was by permission of Allah that He might make evident the [true] believers.

And that He might make evident those who are hypocrites. For it was said to them, "Come, fight in the way of Allah or [at least] defend." They said, "If we had known [there would be] fighting, we would have followed you." They were nearer to disbelief that day than to faith, saying with their mouths what was not in their hearts. And Allah is most Knowing of what they conceal -
Those who said about their brothers while sitting [at home], "If they had obeyed us, they would not have been killed." Say, "Then prevent death from yourselves, if you should be truthful."
And never think of those who have been killed in the cause of Allah as dead. Rather, they are alive with their Lord, receiving provision,
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 9
Indeed, death only changes their states [ahwal] and severs their distractions [shawaghil] and obstacles ['awa'iq] and frees them from their confinement [habs], but as for annihilating them, no. "And never think of those who have been killed in the way of Allah as dead. Rather, they are alive with their Lord, receiving provision, Rejoicing in what Allah has bestowed upon them of His bounty, and they receive good tidings about those [to be martyred] after them who have not yet joined them..." (Qur'an 3:169-170). And do not think that this is specific to the one killed in battle, for the knower ['arif] has for every soul a degree of a thousand martyrs. And in the report: "Indeed, the martyr [shahid] wishes in the Hereafter [Akhirah] to be returned to the world [dunya] to be killed again, for the greatness of what he sees of the reward of martyrdom [shahadah]. And indeed, the martyrs wish they had been knowers ['ulama'] for what they see of the exalted station [darajah] of the knowers."
Vol1 book 9
Indeed, the martyrs [shuhada'] are alive with their Lord, receiving provision [yurzaqun]. And the one attached to the servants [al-ghulman] is the one who transgresses in the means [asbab], and the servants [al-ghulman] who are subjugated are the means [asbab]. And the one sitting in the open of the arena [meydan], in full view of the servants [al-ghulman], are those who reside in the cities [amsar] in the frontier posts [ribatat] and mosques [masajid] in a state of stillness [sukun]. And those hidden in the corners [zawayā] are the wanderers [sa'ihun] in the deserts [bawadi] in a state of reliance [tawakkul], and the means [asbab] follow them and provision [rizq] comes to them, except on the path of rarity [nadur]. For if one of them dies hungry, content [radiyan], then for him is martyrdom [shahada] and nearness [qurb] to God, the Exalted.

a.g: Rejoicing in what Allah has bestowed upon them of His bounty, and they receive good tidings about those [to be martyred] after them who have not yet joined them - that there will be no fear concerning them, nor will they grieve.
They receive good tidings of favor from Allah and bounty and [of the fact] that Allah does not allow the reward of believers to be lost -
Those [believers] who responded to Allah and the Messenger after injury had struck them. For those who did good among them and feared Allah is a great reward -

Those to whom hypocrites said, "Indeed, the people have gathered against you, so fear them." But it [merely] increased them in faith, and they said, "Sufficient for us is Allah, and [He is] the best Disposer of affairs."
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 9
Indeed, there is no power [ḥawl] and no strength [quwwah] except with Allah, the Most High, the Most Great. And sufficient for us is Allah, and what an excellent Trustee [Wakīl] He is.

a.g: So they returned with favor from Allah and bounty, no harm having touched them. And they pursued the pleasure of Allah, and Allah is the possessor of great bounty.
That is only Satan who frightens [you] of his supporters. So fear them not, but fear Me, if you are [indeed] believers.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book4
Indeed, fear of the future [al-mustaqbal] should not occur when God has granted you the sustenance [qūt] of your day for you and your dependents, except from a weakness of certainty [yaqīn] and from heeding the intimidation of Satan [al-shayṭān]. And the Exalted has said: "So do not fear them, but fear Me, if you are believers." And the Mighty and Majestic has said: "Satan threatens you with poverty and commands you to immorality [al-faḥshā'], while God promises you forgiveness from Him and bounty." And begging [al-su'āl] is from the immoralities [al-faḥshā'] which are only permitted out of necessity [al-ḍarūra].

a.g: And do not be grieved, [O Muhammad], by those who hasten into disbelief. Indeed, they will never harm Allah at all. Allah intends that He should give them no share in the Hereafter, and for them is a great punishment.
Indeed, those who purchase disbelief [in exchange] for faith - never will they harm Allah at all, and for them is a painful punishment.

And let not those who disbelieve ever think that [because] We extend their time [of enjoyment] it is better for them. We only extend it for them so that they may increase in sin, and for them is a humiliating punishment.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book 10a
Indeed, if you say: "How can I rejoice when I see a group whose disobedience [ma'siya] has exceeded my own, yet they have not been afflicted with what has afflicted me—even the disbelievers [kuffar]?" Then know that for the disbeliever [kafir] has been stored what is greater. He is only granted respite so that he may increase in sin [ithm] and his punishment ['iqab] be prolonged, as the Most High has said: "We only grant them respite that they may increase in sin [ithm]." As for the acts of disobedience [ma'asi], from where do you know that in the world ['alam] there is one who is more disobedient than you? Perhaps a thought [khatir] of poor etiquette concerning Allah, the Most High, and His attributes is greater and more grievous than drinking wine, fornication [zina], and all other sins [ma'asi] of the limbs. For this reason, the Most High said concerning its like: "And you consider it trivial, but it is, with Allah, immense." So from where do you know that another is more disobedient than you? Then perhaps his punishment ['iqab] has been delayed for the Hereafter [Akhira], while your punishment ['iqab] was hastened in this world [dunya]. So why do you not give thanks [shukr] to Allah, the Most High, for that? This is the third aspect of thankfulness [shukr], which is that there is no punishment ['iqab] except that it is conceivable for it to be delayed until the Hereafter [Akhira]. The afflictions [masa'ib] of this world [dunya] are consoled by other means which lessen the affliction [musiba], so its impact is lightened. But the affliction [musiba] of the Hereafter [Akhira] is everlasting, and even if it were not everlasting, there is no way to lighten it through consolation, for the means of consolation are completely cut off in the Hereafter [Akhira] for those being punished. And for one whose punishment ['iqab] was hastened in this world [dunya], he is not punished a second time, for the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, when a servant ['abd] commits a sin [dhanb] and is then afflicted with hardship or tribulation in this world [dunya], Allah is more Noble than to punish him a second time."
Vol4 book2
Indeed, if you say: "How can I rejoice when I see a group whose disobedience [ma'siya] has exceeded my own, yet they have not been afflicted with what has afflicted me—even the disbelievers [kuffar]?" Then know that for the disbeliever [kafir] has been stored what is greater. He is only granted respite so that he may increase in sin [ithm] and his punishment ['iqab] be prolonged, as the Most High has said: "We only grant them respite that they may increase in sin [ithm]." As for the acts of disobedience [ma'asi], from where do you know that in the world ['alam] there is one who is more disobedient than you? Perhaps a thought [khatir] of poor etiquette concerning Allah, the Most High, and His attributes is greater and more grievous than drinking wine, fornication [zina], and all other sins [ma'asi] of the limbs. For this reason, the Most High said concerning its like: "And you consider it trivial, but it is, with Allah, immense." So from where do you know that another is more disobedient than you? Then perhaps his punishment ['iqab] has been delayed for the Hereafter [Akhira], while your punishment ['iqab] was hastened in this world [dunya]. So why do you not give thanks [shukr] to Allah, the Most High, for that? a.g: Allah would not leave the believers in that [state] you are in [presently] until He separates the evil from the good. Nor would Allah reveal to you the unseen. But [instead], Allah chooses of His messengers whom He wills, so believe in Allah and His messengers. And if you believe and fear Him, then for you is a great reward.

And let not those who [greedily] withhold what Allah has given them of His bounty ever think that it is better for them. Rather, it is worse for them. Their necks will be encircled by what they withheld on the Day of Resurrection. And to Allah belongs the heritage of the heavens and the earth. And Allah, with what you do, is [fully] Acquainted.

Indeed, whoever is facilitated for this journey [safar] will not cease in his travel to be delighting in a garden whose width is the heavens and the earth, while he is settled in body [badan] and established in his homeland. And it is the journey in which the watering places [manahil] and sources [mawārid] do not become constricted, nor does crowding [tazāhum] and convergence [tawārud] cause harm within it. Rather, its spoils [ghanā'im] increase with the multitude of travelers, and its fruits [thamarat] and benefits multiply. Its spoils are permanent, not forbidden, and its fruits are ever-increasing, not severed—unless a pause [fatra] appears for the traveler in his journey and a halt in his movement. For indeed, Allah does not change what is in a people until they change what is in themselves. And if they deviate, Allah causes their hearts [qulūb] to deviate. And Allah is not unjust to the servants, but they are unjust to themselves.

a.g: [They are] those who said, "Indeed, Allah has taken our promise not to believe any messenger until he brings us an offering which fire [from heaven] will consume." Say, "There have already come to you messengers before me with clear proofs and [even] that of which you speak. So why did you kill them, if you should be truthful?"
Then if they deny you, [O Muhammad] - so were messengers denied before you, who brought clear proofs and written ordinances and the enlightening Scripture.

Every soul will taste death, and you will only be given your [full] compensation on the Day of Resurrection. So he who is drawn away from the Fire and admitted to Paradise has attained [his desire]. And what is the life of this world except the enjoyment of delusion.

Indeed, while I was journeying on a journey of mine, I turned aside to a tree to rest beneath it, and there I was with an elder who had drawn near to death [ashrafa 'ala al-mawt]. He said to me: 'O this one, arise, for Death [al-Mawt] has not died.' Then he wandered off, and I followed him. I heard him saying: 'Every soul shall taste death [kullu nafsin dha'iqatu al-mawt]. O Allah, bless me in death [al-mawt].' So I said: 'And in what is after death [ma ba'da al-mawt]?' He said: 'Whoever is certain [man ayaqana] by what is after death [ma ba'da al-mawt] has rolled up the hem of caution [mizar al-hadhr], and for him in the world [al-dunya] there is no abiding place [mustaqarr].'

a.g: You will surely be tested in your possessions and in yourselves. And you will surely hear from those who were given the Scripture before you and from those who associate others with Allah much abuse. But if you are patient and fear Allah - indeed, that is of the matters [worthy] of determination.

And [mention, O Muhammad], when Allah took a covenant from those who were given the Scripture, [saying], "You must make it clear to the people and not conceal it." But they threw it away behind their backs and exchanged it for a small price. And wretched is that which they purchased.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 1
Indeed, God Almighty said: "To make it clear to the people and not conceal it." And know that the easiest thing you have committed and the lightest burden you have borne is that you brought comfort to the loneliness of the wrongdoer [al-zalim] and smoothed the path of transgression [al-baghy] by drawing near to one who neither fulfilled a right nor abandoned a falsehood. When they drew you near, they took you as an axis [qutb] upon which the millstone of their injustice revolves, and as a bridge [jisr] over which they cross to their calamity, and as a ladder [sullam] upon which they ascend to their misguidance. And through you, they introduce doubt [al-shakk] to the people of knowledge [al-'ulama'], and through you, they ensnare the hearts [qulub] of the ignorant [al-jahilun]. So how trivial is what they built compared to what they destroyed for you, and how much they took from you in what they corrupted of your religion [din]! So what assures you that you are not among those about whom God Almighty said: "But there succeeded after them successors who neglected prayer..."? And indeed, you are dealing with One who is not ignorant, and an account is kept of you by One who is not heedless. So treat your religion [din], for sickness has entered it, and prepare your provision [zad], for a long journey [safar] has drawn near. And nothing is hidden from God of anything in the earth or in the heaven.

a.g: And never think that those who rejoice in what they have perpetrated and like to be praised for what they did not do - never think them [to be] in safety from the punishment, and for them is a painful punishment.
And to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth, and Allah is over all things competent.
Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs for those of understanding.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book2
Indeed, as Allah the Exalted has said: "Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs [ayat] for those of understanding [ulu al-albab]." And from 'Ata', he said: I set out one day, I and 'Ubayd ibn 'Umayr, to 'A'isha, may Allah be pleased with her. She spoke to us, and between us and her was a veil [hijab]. She said: "O 'Ubayd, what prevents you from visiting us?" He said: "The saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Visit infrequently, and love will increase.'" Ibn 'Umayr said: "So inform us of the most wondrous thing you saw from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him." She wept and said: "All of his affair was wondrous. He came to me in my night until his skin touched my skin. Then he said: 'Leave me to worship my Lord, the Mighty and Majestic.'" He rose to the water-skin and performed ablution from it. Then he stood to pray and wept until his beard became wet. Then he prostrated until the ground became wet. Then he lay on his side until Bilal came to give the call for the dawn prayer. He said: "O Messenger of Allah, what makes you weep when Allah has forgiven you your preceding and forthcoming sin?" He said: "Woe to you, O Bilal! And what prevents me from weeping when Allah the Exalted has revealed to me this night: 'Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs [ayat] for those of understanding [ulu al-albab].'" Then he said: "Woe to the one who recites it and does not reflect [yatafakkar] upon it."

a.g: And their Lord responded to them, "Never will I allow to be lost the work of [any] worker among you, whether male or female; you are of one another. So those who emigrated or were evicted from their homes or were harmed in My cause or fought or were killed - I will surely remove from them their misdeeds, and I will surely admit them to gardens beneath which rivers flow as reward from Allah, and Allah has with Him the best reward."
Be not deceived by the [uninhibited] movement of the disbelievers throughout the land.
[It is but] a small enjoyment; then their [final] refuge is Hell, and wretched is the resting place.
But those who feared their Lord will have gardens beneath which rivers flow, abiding eternally therein, as accommodation from Allah. And that which is with Allah is best for the righteous.

Indeed, belief [iman] by mere affirmation [tasdiq] is that one affirms [yusaddiq] Allah, the Exalted, in His saying, Mighty and Majestic: "And what is with Allah is better." And indeed, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, informed groups of the disbelievers of that, and they followed him and affirmed him and believed in him, and they did not demand proof [burhan] from him. And among them were those who said: "We adjure you by Allah, did Allah send you as a messenger?" And he would say: "Yes," and they would affirm. And this is the faith [iman] of the common people [al-'ammah], and it delivers from delusion [ghurur]. And this is placed in the same position as the child's affirmation of his father that attending the school [al-maktab] is better than attending the playground [al-mala'ab], even though he does not know the aspect of its being better.

a.g: O you who have believed, persevere and endure and remain stationed and fear Allah that you may be successful.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book2
Indeed, the possessors of insight [arbab al-basa'ir] from among the servants have come to know that God, Exalted is He, lies in wait for them [lahum bil-mirsad], and that they will be called to account [yunaqqashun fil-hisab] and will be held to task for the weight of an atom [mithaqil adh-dharr] from passing thoughts [khawatir] and glances [lahthat]. And they have realized with certainty [tahaqqu] that nothing will save them from these perils except adhering to self-reckoning [luzum al-muhasaba] and sincerity in self-vigilance [sidq al-muraqaba], and holding the soul [nafs] to account for every breath [anfas] and movement [harakat], and reckoning with it for every passing thought [khawatir] and glance [lahthat]. For whoever holds his soul to account before he is held to account, his reckoning on the Day of Standing [al-qiyamah] will be lightened, his answer will be present when questioned, and his return and his final destination [ma'ab] will be good. And whoever does not hold his soul to account, his regrets [hasrat] will be prolonged, and his stations [waqfat] in the plains ['arasat] of the Day of Standing will be lengthy, and his misdeeds [sayyi'at] will lead him to disgrace and contempt. When this was unveiled to them, they knew that nothing would save them from it except obedience to God. And He had commanded them to patience [sabr] and steadfast vigilance [murabata], so He, Mighty and Majestic is He, said: "O you who believe, be patient, and vie in patience, and be steadfast, and fear God, that you may succeed." So they made their souls steadfastly vigilant [rabatu anfusahum] first through mutual pledging [al-musharata], then through self-vigilance [al-muraqaba], then through self-reckoning [al-muhasaba], then through self-chastisement [al-mu'aqaba], then through spiritual struggle [al-mujahada], then through self-admonition [al-mu'ataba]. Thus, for them in steadfast vigilance [al-murabata] were six stations [maqamat], and it is necessary to explain them, clarify their reality [haqiqa] and their virtue [fadila], and detail the works within them. The foundation of all that is self-reckoning [al-muhasaba], but every reckoning [hisab] comes after mutual pledging [musharata] and self-vigilance [muraqaba], and is followed, in case of loss [khusran], by self-admonition [mu'ataba] and self-chastisement [mu'aqaba].
